Award.AwardTitle: Searching for New Phenomena with Leptons
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the major intellectual achievements of the 20th century was the development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. This model succeeded in classifying all of the elementary particles known at the time into a hierarchy of groups having similar quantum properties. The validity of this model to date was recently confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the CERN laboratory near Geneva Switzerland. However, the Standard Model as it currently exists leaves open many questions about the universe, including such fundamental questions as to why the mass of the Higgs boson has the value it has. To answer these questions it is necessary to go beyond the present picture of the Universe described by the Standard Model to the next phase of development, Beyond the Standard Model (BSM). Investigations in BSM physics probe such questions as why matter dominates over anti-matter in the Universe, the values of the masses of the fundamental constituents of matter, the quarks and the leptons, the size of the mixings among the quarks, and separately among the leptons, and the properties of dark matter. This project, which uses the Mu2e detector at Fermilab, will search for BSM physics through the precision measurement of the energy of electrons produced by the decay of muons. The broader impact of this work, in addition to contributions to the scientific collaborations, includes student engagement at Northern Illinois University, public outreach and service, and technology development through generation of patents and the development of technology usable for medical imaging. Undergraduate and graduate students from both physics and engineering participate in all aspects of this research. Technology developed by the R&D program has expanded techniques available for calorimetry and is currently being used for Mu2e and for a second generation proton tomography device, and has led to two patents with a third under consideration.

Searches for evidence for new physics beyond the Standard Model can be addressed through direct searches at the Energy Frontier at High Energy Colliding Beam Facilities such as the LHC and through a complementary technique of indirect searches at the Intensity Frontier, in experimental measurements of rare processes such the subject of this award, the decay of a muon into an electron. In the SM such a decay is very rare, but certain BSM physics models, such as SuperSymmetry(SUSY) , predict a higher rate of this decay. In this award, the researchers will use the Mu2e detector at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (FNAL). This experiment uses a very intense beam of protons to produce a muon beam which traverses a series of magnets and impinges on a target where the muons are stopped and are captured by Aluminum atoms in the target. After a short period of time, the muons then decay to electrons and if the decay is a direct decay to an electron (with no neutrino) the electron has a unique characteristic energy. The challenge of this experiment is to measure the electron energy very precisely. If the electron energy distribution is correct, it will show evidence of the direct muon to electron decay and provide evidence that there is BSM physics.

Intellectual Impacts:

The two emphases of this project were the searches for new physics and the development of enabling detector technologies for these investigations. There are a number of persuasive reasons to believe that the Standard Model of particle physics cannot be considered the full story and as such explorations of deviations from it have acquired key importance. These explorations can be carried out by directly searching for particles, that this new physics may engender, as in the case of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) or by making precision measurements and searches for rare decays of known particles to perceive the indirect impact of this new physics. The Mu2e experiment, one of the foci of this project, is such an experiment looking for the neutrino-less conversion of a muon to an electron. As an example of charged lepton flavor violation, both, the discovery or non-observation of this signal will significantly impact our understanding of physics beyond the Standard Model. This project delivered on simulation and design studies, testing and characterization of elements critical to the performance of the experiment. This has included studies of the neutron background, design of the muon beam stop, engineering studies for the cosmic ray veto (CRV) detector and responsibility for its photosensors. As reference, the CRV comprised of approximately 5500 scintillator strips using WLS fibers mated to silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) photosensors will cover the detector hall and use 20K SiPMs. The CRV operating at 99.99% efficiency is key to identifying and rejecting cosmic induced background, which would otherwise swamp the experiment.

The project has also been involved with detector R&D studies critical to the performance of detectors of upgrading or future experiments. These technologies will allow for the superior performance of detectors in challenging environments so as to extract the coveted physics. One such challenging environment is the cryogenic one as in a Liquid Argon Time Projection Chamber (LArTPC). This project was instrumental in carrying out critical studies on photosensors (SiPMs) for the Single-phase photon detector system for the DUNE experiment. The photon system will play a key role in exploiting the physics potential of the DUNE experiment (a global neutrino laboratory) especially for non-beam events. Also of interest to future high energy particle, astroparticle, and neutrino experiments will be compact, high-granularity calorimetry with improved position and energy resolution, imaging of spatial and temporal development of showers, and robust reconstruction efficiency in high density particle environments. This project has contributed to the successful R&D program carried out by the NIU group on scintillator-SiPM calorimetry using the direct (i.e. fiberless) coupling of small dimpled tiles to surface mount SiPMs that are mounted on a printed circuit board that sits inside the detector and also carries the tiles and the front-end electronics and the associated signal and bias traces.

 

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of this project were extensive, including interdisciplinary undergraduate and graduate student engagement at NIU and elsewhere, public outreach and service, and engagement with K-12 science teachers and students.  The NIU HEP program has a particularly strong collaboration with the NIU College of Engineering and Engineering Technology, with productive collaboration with faculty, undergraduate students, and graduate students in projects related to the CMS, Mu2e projects.  Innovative detector technologies developed through the efforts described in this proposal have been or are planned to be utilized in other experiments and led to two patents and an invention disclosure.
